Skin changes (e.g., new moles, changes in existing moles, jaundice).
Changes in skin color or texture.
changes in bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation).
rectal bleeding or blood in stool.
jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes).
feeling of fullness after eating small amounts.
pain or discomfort in the upper abdomen after eating.
Changes in cognitive function, such as memory problems, confusion, or difficulty concentrating.
Speech difficulties, including slurring, difficulty finding words (aphasia), or changes in voice quality.
Problems with balance, coordination, or gait (walking).
Changes in sleep patterns, such as insomnia or excessive sleepiness.
Changes in bowel or bladder control (incontinence or retention).
Changes in mood or personality, including depression, anxiety, or irritability.
Numbness or altered sensation in the face, hands, or feet.
Difficulty with fine motor skills, such as writing or buttoning clothes.
Chest pain (angina), which may radiate to the arm, jaw, or back.
Swelling in the ankles, feet, or abdomen (edema).
Coughing, especially when lying down (cardiac cough).
Bluish discoloration of the skin or lips (cyanosis).
Changes in skin color or temperature in the extremities.
Weakness or numbness in the limbs.
Sweating, especially with chest pain or exertion.
Sudden weight gain (due to fluid retention).
Confusion or difficulty thinking (in severe cases).
Changes in bowel or bladder habits.
